data.name: Dictionary - SAFE finding a description
data.description:
Task description
----------------

Simple kata to safetly go thru arrays.
Be aware of incorrect inputs.

You have to implement 2 functions: `findDescription` and `countWords`.

findDescription:
----------------
Should find given `word` in given `dictionary` and return it's description.
~~~if:javascript
`dictionary` is array which consist of:
```javascript
{
    keys;
    description;
}
`keys` will be [] of strings or nulls. Could be also `null`.
`description` will be string or null.
```
~~~
~~~if:typescript
`dictionary` is array which consist of (preloaded) interface:
```typescript
interface WordDescription {
    keys: (string | null)[] | null;
    description: string | null;
}
```
~~~
Each element in given array will be called: `entry` (our `dictionary entry`).

Example entry:
```typescript
{
    keys: ['home', 'house'];
    description: 'Place where you live.';
}
```

`keys` can have more than one entry (synonyms).

Matching requested `word` to `keys` in our dictionary should be case insensitive.

When there is no valid solution return empty string.

Corruped entries:
-----------------
Sometimes there can be `corrupted entry`, so you should make your solution bullet-proof safe.

`Corruped entries` are when entry has no keys or has empty description.

Depends on language (where `null` is assignable) `null` keys or `null` description should be also treated as corrupted.

Example corruped entry:
-----------------------
```typescript
{
    keys: [];
    description: null;
}
```

countWords
----------

Your goal is to count words in given `description`.
`It's` (and such words) should be counted as `1`.
Same goes for words like `son-in-law`.
Valid word has to have at least one letter.
Valid word can have `-` and `'` inside it, but such characters cannot be at start nor end of word.
If there is no valid words or input is empty - return 0.

Examples:

`"Simple, short description for start."` should return `5`

`""` should return `0`.

`"1. ###"` should return `0`.

Note:
-----
* All valid descriptions will consist of single line only (no line breakes).
* Provided dictionary will have at most 1 definition for given `word`.
